CHAS. CARROLL CLUB
ELECTS OFFICERS
John V. Lyons was elected
president of the Charles Carroll Club last Sunday. The
other officers and their positions are as follows: Robert
T. Kyle, vice-president; Michael J. Romano, treasurer;
Lilly E. Lavarello, recording
secretary; Angela Eckenrode,
corresponding secretary. ,
The election of the officers
was held in the Mechanical
Engineering Building. The
meeting was the final one of
the year.

GRADUATE FRATERNITY
FOUNDED AT HOPKINS
Eight Graduates Form Chapter
of Chi Psi Omega
With a group of eight charter
members for a nucelus, a new chapter of a graduate fraternity has
been organized at Hopkins during
the past month.
The chapter here will be known
as the "Daniel Coit Gilman Chapter" of Chi Psi Omega. As other
Hopkins institutions have in the
past extended their influence over
the country, so will this new organization attempt to develop a cosmopolitan nature which will extend its
sphere of action to distant places.
Graduate students and instructors
who are graduates of Hopkins will
be eligible for membership which
will not be restricted to men working in any particular field, but will
include those doing work in all
realms of graduate research. The
fraternity will endeavor also to
make its membership as widely representative of all nations as is possible.
Its meetings, besides giving time
to purely social activities and good
fellowship, devote a certain period
to discussions of a more formal
nature when papers are read and
discussed by the group relating to
the various interests of the members.
The officers include a Chancellor,
Vice-Chancellor, Keeper of the
Rolls, Keeper of the Exchequer,
and a Marshal.
Because there is no organization
on the campus at present which is
of such a universal nature, it is felt
the fraternity will fill a long-needed
want, both in providing good fellowship for its membership and in
enabling them to acquire a wider
outlook on other realms of work
beside their own.
• The chapter which was officially
installed the end of April is not
desirous of making its membership
public at this time, but will do so
early in the fall.

JUNIOR CLASS TO
HOLD SECOND DANCE
Tomorrow night the Junior
Class will hold its second
dance in the Civil Engineering
Hall.
The dance will be of the
regular informal Saturdaynight variety.
Simpson - Morris' six-piece
orchestra will furnish the music, which is scheduled to
start at 9 o'clock.
The proceeds will go toward making up the deficit
left by the last dance, and the
price will be $1.50 per couple
and $1.00 stag.

A REAL
CAMPUS NEED

L

With graduation to be or not to be in little more than a little
month, a senior may perhaps be pardoned for pondering on an
old question—a question which, like that of Hamlet's sanity, has
been so much discussed that it is becoming rather tiresome. But—
Is college worth the price?
Every now and then the powers tell us that a tuition fee amounts
to no more than a small fraction of the actual expense of turning
out a Bachelor of Arts. True, we might say to them, but a tuition
fee for most students is a large sum, no matter what portion of
the total expense it pays and, furthermore, the tuition is not the
whole price we must pay, nor is it the most important part of the
whole price. After all, we must have a place to sleep, clothes to
wear, food to eat, and an occasional modern book, even when we
are undergraduates. And our most costly offering to the Alma
Mater has yet to be mentioned: the precious years of youth we
give her. Is it then untimely to consider again that old question?
It seems to me that graduation without a strong conviction in an
affirmative answer would be quite a hollow success.
Unfortunately, my answer is conditional. If one has passed
from childhood and adolescence well into a genuine adult attitude
toward life, college has been worth whatever price he has paid.
H. G. Wells, in The World of William Clissold, gives me the
special connotations for my terms "childhood," "adolescence" and
"adult." He says: "We grow out of belief. All children are
naturally believers. They begin with a sense of being completely
protected. . . . But we who really go right through into the completely adult stage come out beyond any sense of providence and
responsibility. We know we are exposed and unprotected." I
know the thousand other answers to my question. I have heard
men point out the value of college friendships, the value of rubbing
shoulders with larger minds, the value of what practical information we accumulate, the value of the culture which inevitably comes
to the better university men but all these, I say, are of minor
importance when mental attitude is considered.
If the young A. B. still believes in protection, in providence
and responsibility, he has tossed away his purse for nothing. He
is a child. But if he knows he is alone—exposed and unprotected,
with no providence caring for him—then he has spent wisely.
And if this realization thrills him, rather like the smell of acrid
smoke does the old soldier, then he has a chance. . . .

LEVERING HALL AGAIN

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS

To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir:

The degree to which libel and
slander will be tolerated in a college
publication at Michigan State has
been rather forcibly pointed out by
Dean Robert S. Shaw of that institution. The managing editor of a
student paper, published on the campus but unrecognized by the college
officials, was recently summarily suspended from college by the Dean as
the result of an editorial to which
,he confessed authorship. In his
attempted masterpiece for some reason or other, the now former editoi
stated that "the college is not a college at all, but a political playground
where the college presidency is a bait
for party electioneers and a State
institution for governors to practice
economy or to cover up grafts elsewhere in the machine." He queried
further in his sweeping statement,
"What can one expect from such a
condition where corruption and graft
reign?" Affirming later his evident
belief in his own superiority, the
misguided youth declared that "one
could not expect to find many students of an intellectual nature, since
they had all been scared away by
the political bugaboo and the unintellectual atmosphere."
* * *
Rather unforeseen events have
occurred to a student at the University of Minnesota as the result of
his writing a story on Arabia and
the Foreign Legion. Because of the
exceedingly realistic quality of this
work, the report became widespread
that the youth was a deserter of the
Foreign Legion and was wanted by
that outfit. There was some little
confusion before the matter was
finally clarified and the student's repeated assertions of his innocence
were accepted.

Displacing the present curriculum
of twenty years' standing, a revised
program of undergraduate instruction, intended to open new and more
extensive fields to the student, will
be effected at Columbia next September. It is intended that the
freshman and sophomore years will
be devoted to "orientation and discovery," while the last two will be
given to study in preparation for
graduate or professional work. On
the subject of this plan and its aims
President Nicholas Murray Butler
recently stated: "Every effort has
been made to measure progress toward the bachelor's degree in terms
of real achievement rather than in
that of prescribed courses, hours,
points or anything of that nature.
A student who can show that he is
competent of omitting any of the
courses ordinarily prescribed for
the undergraduate will be encouraged to do so." All of which sounds
worthy of a trial or at least of investigation.
* * *

The subject of Levering Hall is
one on which every one who is no
one feels compelled, at one time or
another, to air his opinions in ink,
if I have not mixed metaphors. I
think I have read nearly all that has
been written on the matter, and I
find a surprising unanimity in one
respect: We are afraid of the Y. M.
C. A.
Apparently the Y. M. C. A. is to
dominate the University and all
things will be under the Y's control.
Pictures, droll pictures, amusing pictures, ridiculous pictures, have been
painted of the placarded interior of
a militant religious center. Imaginations have had the grandest frolic
in years, coursing up and down
through the Levering Hall-to-be.
And through it all we are afraid of
the Y. M. C. A.
Small wonder that we fear, I suppose. See how the Y is situated
now: Solidly intrenched in the
Barn, the "Heart of the Campus,"
in the very center of all activities,
it saps the strength of all and extends its grasping fingers even into
the Athletic Office, so that the
coaches tremble when the Y is mentioned. Like a canker it grows,
adding new members every week,
yes, every day—so that there are
almost a dozen men in the organization who are willing to work
heart and soul for its cause.
Pause and reflect how all this
would be furthered by -Levering
Hall. The walls would be papered
with posters, we understand, and
any person who rides through our
countryside papered with Chesterfield ads, and still clings to his
Luckys should realize the power of
such "propaganda." And "Doc"
Adams, in taking over the new cafeteria, would immediately find himself under the Y's control and would
be prohibited from selling any sort
of deviled egg sandwich. Perhaps
even short chocolates and short
change would be put in the same
class. And the NEWS-LETTER, 110W
dominated by the Y. M.C. A., would
find itself, as soon as it moved into
the new activities building, completely taken over by the "Y." And as
a last thought—think what would
happen to the Blue Jay!
Thus can the imagination play
but this much can be said with complete surety: instead of twelve active
workers in the "Y," a much larger
number, say thirteen at least, would
carry on the despotic purposes of
the organization. This must not be!
Thirteen "Y" workers on our campus? Never!

Hopkins Engineer to
Aid Roads Bureau
Under a co-operative agreement
between the Johns Hopkins University and the United States Bureau
of Public Roads J. Truman Thompson, Associate Professor of Civil
Engineering, will supervise research
work to check field measurements
carried out during the summer of
1927 by the United States Bureau
of Public Roads in co-operation
with the State Highway Commission of North Carolina. .
This work had to do with the
measurement of stresses in the multiple span reinforced concrete highway arch bridge over the Yadkin
River in North Carolina. During
the period of investigation, the government engineers worked with
those of the State and finally completed measurements of stresses
that were undergone by the bridge
due to heavy loads which they imposed upon it.
After the completion of these
various measurements, the bridge
v1/4ras bombed by planes of the Army
Air Service, then subjected to the
heavy fire of artillery. It was
finally demolished completely by
Army engineers who mined its
piers. During the past winter pictures were shown in Baltimore motion-picture houses of the destruction of the bridge.
A celluloid model of the demolished bridge will be very carefully
constructed and then Professor
Thompson will check the field measurements of the government and
North Carolina engineers by observing the microscopic movements
of the model.

CHAS. CARROLL CLUB
ELECTS OFFICERS
John V. Lyons was elected
president of the Charles Carroll Club last Sunday. The
other officers and their positions are as follows: Robert
T. Kyle, vice-president; Michael J. Romano, treasurer;
Lilly E. Lavarello, recording
secretary; Angela Eckenrode,
corresponding secretary. ,
The election of the officers
was held in the Mechanical
Engineering Building. The
meeting was the final one of
the year.

GRADUATE FRATERNITY
FOUNDED AT HOPKINS
Eight Graduates Form Chapter
of Chi Psi Omega
With a group of eight charter
members for a nucelus, a new chapter of a graduate fraternity has
been organized at Hopkins during
the past month.
The chapter here will be known
as the "Daniel Coit Gilman Chapter" of Chi Psi Omega. As other
Hopkins institutions have in the
past extended their influence over
the country, so will this new organization attempt to develop a cosmopolitan nature which will extend its
sphere of action to distant places.
Graduate students and instructors
who are graduates of Hopkins will
be eligible for membership which
will not be restricted to men working in any particular field, but will
include those doing work in all
realms of graduate research. The
fraternity will endeavor also to
make its membership as widely representative of all nations as is possible.
Its meetings, besides giving time
to purely social activities and good
fellowship, devote a certain period
to discussions of a more formal
nature when papers are read and
discussed by the group relating to
the various interests of the members.
The officers include a Chancellor,
Vice-Chancellor, Keeper of the
Rolls, Keeper of the Exchequer,
and a Marshal.
Because there is no organization
on the campus at present which is
of such a universal nature, it is felt
the fraternity will fill a long-needed
want, both in providing good fellowship for its membership and in
enabling them to acquire a wider
outlook on other realms of work
beside their own.
• The chapter which was officially
installed the end of April is not
desirous of making its membership
public at this time, but will do so
early in the fall.

JUNIOR CLASS TO
HOLD SECOND DANCE
Tomorrow night the Junior
Class will hold its second
dance in the Civil Engineering
Hall.
The dance will be of the
regular informal Saturdaynight variety.
Simpson - Morris' six-piece
orchestra will furnish the music, which is scheduled to
start at 9 o'clock.
The proceeds will go toward making up the deficit
left by the last dance, and the
price will be $1.50 per couple
and $1.00 stag.

A REAL
CAMPUS NEED

L

With graduation to be or not to be in little more than a little
month, a senior may perhaps be pardoned for pondering on an
old question—a question which, like that of Hamlet's sanity, has
been so much discussed that it is becoming rather tiresome. But—
Is college worth the price?
Every now and then the powers tell us that a tuition fee amounts
to no more than a small fraction of the actual expense of turning
out a Bachelor of Arts. True, we might say to them, but a tuition
fee for most students is a large sum, no matter what portion of
the total expense it pays and, furthermore, the tuition is not the
whole price we must pay, nor is it the most important part of the
whole price. After all, we must have a place to sleep, clothes to
wear, food to eat, and an occasional modern book, even when we
are undergraduates. And our most costly offering to the Alma
Mater has yet to be mentioned: the precious years of youth we
give her. Is it then untimely to consider again that old question?
It seems to me that graduation without a strong conviction in an
affirmative answer would be quite a hollow success.
Unfortunately, my answer is conditional. If one has passed
from childhood and adolescence well into a genuine adult attitude
toward life, college has been worth whatever price he has paid.
H. G. Wells, in The World of William Clissold, gives me the
special connotations for my terms "childhood," "adolescence" and
"adult." He says: "We grow out of belief. All children are
naturally believers. They begin with a sense of being completely
protected. . . . But we who really go right through into the completely adult stage come out beyond any sense of providence and
responsibility. We know we are exposed and unprotected." I
know the thousand other answers to my question. I have heard
men point out the value of college friendships, the value of rubbing
shoulders with larger minds, the value of what practical information we accumulate, the value of the culture which inevitably comes
to the better university men but all these, I say, are of minor
importance when mental attitude is considered.
If the young A. B. still believes in protection, in providence
and responsibility, he has tossed away his purse for nothing. He
is a child. But if he knows he is alone—exposed and unprotected,
with no providence caring for him—then he has spent wisely.
And if this realization thrills him, rather like the smell of acrid
smoke does the old soldier, then he has a chance. . . .

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, MAY 18, 1928
LEVERING HALL AGAIN

INTERCOLLEGIATE
NEWS

To the Editor of the NEWS-LETTER.
Dear Sir:

The degree to which libel and
slander will be tolerated in a college
publication at Michigan State has
been rather forcibly pointed out by
Dean Robert S. Shaw of that institution. The managing editor of a
student paper, published on the campus but unrecognized by the college
officials, was recently summarily suspended from college by the Dean as
the result of an editorial to which
,he confessed authorship. In his
attempted masterpiece for some reason or other, the now former editoi
stated that "the college is not a college at all, but a political playground
where the college presidency is a bait
for party electioneers and a State
institution for governors to practice
economy or to cover up grafts elsewhere in the machine." He queried
further in his sweeping statement,
"What can one expect from such a
condition where corruption and graft
reign?" Affirming later his evident
belief in his own superiority, the
misguided youth declared that "one
could not expect to find many students of an intellectual nature, since
they had all been scared away by
the political bugaboo and the unintellectual atmosphere."
* * *
Rather unforeseen events have
occurred to a student at the University of Minnesota as the result of
his writing a story on Arabia and
the Foreign Legion. Because of the
exceedingly realistic quality of this
work, the report became widespread
that the youth was a deserter of the
Foreign Legion and was wanted by
that outfit. There was some little
confusion before the matter was
finally clarified and the student's repeated assertions of his innocence
were accepted.
*

*

*

Displacing the present curriculum
of twenty years' standing, a revised
program of undergraduate instruction, intended to open new and more
extensive fields to the student, will
be effected at Columbia next September. It is intended that the
freshman and sophomore years will
be devoted to "orientation and discovery," while the last two will be
given to study in preparation for
graduate or professional work. On
the subject of this plan and its aims
President Nicholas Murray Butler
recently stated: "Every effort has
been made to measure progress toward the bachelor's degree in terms
of real achievement rather than in
that of prescribed courses, hours,
points or anything of that nature.
A student who can show that he is
competent of omitting any of the
courses ordinarily prescribed for
the undergraduate will be encouraged to do so." All of which sounds
worthy of a trial or at least of investigation.
* * *

The subject of Levering Hall is
one on which every one who is no
one feels compelled, at one time or
another, to air his opinions in ink,
if I have not mixed metaphors. I
think I have read nearly all that has
been written on the matter, and I
find a surprising unanimity in one
respect: We are afraid of the Y. M.
C. A.
Apparently the Y. M. C. A. is to
dominate the University and all
things will be under the Y's control.
Pictures, droll pictures, amusing pictures, ridiculous pictures, have been
painted of the placarded interior of
a militant religious center. Imaginations have had the grandest frolic
in years, coursing up and down
through the Levering Hall-to-be.
And through it all we are afraid of
the Y. M. C. A.
Small wonder that we fear, I suppose. See how the Y is situated
now: Solidly intrenched in the
Barn, the "Heart of the Campus,"
in the very center of all activities,
it saps the strength of all and extends its grasping fingers even into
the Athletic Office, so that the
coaches tremble when the Y is mentioned. Like a canker it grows,
adding new members every week,
yes, every day—so that there are
almost a dozen men in the organization who are willing to work
heart and soul for its cause.
Pause and reflect how all this
would be furthered by -Levering
Hall. The walls would be papered
with posters, we understand, and
any person who rides through our
countryside papered with Chesterfield ads, and still clings to his
Luckys should realize the power of
such "propaganda." And "Doc"
Adams, in taking over the new cafeteria, would immediately find himself under the Y's control and would
be prohibited from selling any sort
of deviled egg sandwich. Perhaps
even short chocolates and short
change would be put in the same
class. And the NEWS-LETTER, 110W
dominated by the Y. M.C. A., would
find itself, as soon as it moved into
the new activities building, completely taken over by the "Y." And as
a last thought—think what would
happen to the Blue Jay!
Thus can the imagination play
but this much can be said with complete surety: instead of twelve active
workers in the "Y," a much larger
number, say thirteen at least, would
carry on the despotic purposes of
the organization. This must not be!
Thirteen "Y" workers on our campus? Never!

Hopkins Engineer to
Aid Roads Bureau
Under a co-operative agreement
between the Johns Hopkins University and the United States Bureau
of Public Roads J. Truman Thompson, Associate Professor of Civil
Engineering, will supervise research
work to check field measurements
carried out during the summer of
1927 by the United States Bureau
of Public Roads in co-operation
with the State Highway Commission of North Carolina. .
This work had to do with the
measurement of stresses in the multiple span reinforced concrete highway arch bridge over the Yadkin
River in North Carolina. During
the period of investigation, the government engineers worked with
those of the State and finally completed measurements of stresses
that were undergone by the bridge
due to heavy loads which they imposed upon it.
After the completion of these
various measurements, the bridge
v1/4ras bombed by planes of the Army
Air Service, then subjected to the
heavy fire of artillery. It was
finally demolished completely by
Army engineers who mined its
piers. During the past winter pictures were shown in Baltimore motion-picture houses of the destruction of the bridge.
A celluloid model of the demolished bridge will be very carefully
constructed and then Professor
Thompson will check the field measurements of the government and
North Carolina engineers by observing the microscopic movements
of the model.

FOX & COURTENAY

THE NEWS - LETTER and The
Black and Blue Jay have each been
reduced in this appropriation be
cause it was recognized that these
two publications are self-supporting
and have an outside means of increasing their revenue through the
medium of advertisements. Other
activities rely to a great extent on
the appropriations allowed them.
The Debating Council was granted
an increase because it is not selfsupporting and because its expenses
have, increased by its taking trips.
With the exception of the Debating Council, all activities were reported as being well off financially.
The Blue Jay takes first place in
financial status. THE NEWS-LETTER and the Musical Club were also
reported in good circumstances.
The new Student Activities
Council officers—Richard H. Wood,
President, and George M. Glazier,
Secretary—assumed their offices.
At the meeting four men were
awarded the Varsity Seal. They
are: William Pilic, Hullabaloo;
Christopher Know, Barnstormers;
Edward Wyatt, Barnstormers;
Donald Werner, NEWS-LETTER.

Dr. Ames Presides at
Aviation Conference

At a conference held Wednesday
at Langley Field, Dr. Joseph S.
Ames, dean of the College of Arts
and Sciences, presided at the discussion relating to development of
aeronautics in the past year. Dr.
Ames headed the group of one hundred men representing all phases of
aviation which left Washington
Tuesday night, sailing by boat to
Old Point Comfort.

, The State Department has announced the appointment of Dr.
Frank J. Goodnow to a commission
created by the treaty of conciliation
between China and this country in
1913-14.
Secretary of State Kellogg recently issued the order to fill various vacancies on the commission
which have occurred from time to
time because of the death of its
members. Dr. Goodnow will take
the place of the late Henry White,
who was also a Marylander.
